what can we, mere members of the greater python community, do to help the pypy effort?
You should care because PyPy is more maintainable, faster, and more flexible.
Also, things like stackless Python are written as source code transformations, rather than invasive modifications to the core VM
Also taking questions :)

Because RPython makes it easy to seperate concerns.  The GCs are pluggable, the JIT is orthagonal to the Python language, so if you write a new optimization it automatically applies to the entire source, the language is also "better" than C

RPython is basically Python with restrictions: no generators, and variables must take a single type for a given codepath, no eval/exec either, other than that it's basically Python

Blue sky quesiton: PIL is pretty hard to optimize in certain ways without wholesale rewrites to make things less convoluted. How long before it makes sense to write a pure Python library instead and focus on maintainability?
You say RPython is the language that goes through the JIT, but is there a parser that can understand, e.g. generator code?
and make this into something RPython can digest and inline/optimize?
@alex does PyPy support the full python stdlib?
and what versions of CPython code should I expect to write with it.
@tilgovi The JIT optimizes and inlines your normal Python code at runtime
@tilgovi full stdlib.  current release is 2.5, next will be 2.7
@acdha a pure python image lib would be awesome, and then peopole could do optional C libs for speed where it's important

@alex I wonder if anyone's at all started that - I started playing with backends using e.g. GraphicsMagick but I'd really like to take something like https://github.com/acdha/NativeImaging/blob/master/NativeImaging/api.py as a DBAPI-style base class with a few improvements so it'd be easier to start collecting all of the different format support code. Might have to look into that at PyCon
@acdha when you say DB-API you mean PEP249?
shrug, TBH if it'd make people switch I'd suck it up and just port it by hand, all of PIL
to PyPy that is
Yeah - the main reason I looked outside of PIL is that it doesn't handle JP2 at all and I wasn't jumping to write a decoder
I already ported all of psycopog2
so long as you have tests it's actually really pleasant
I don't know if it is or isn't actively developed, but fredrick is the only one working on it ever AFAIK
I've also been looking on a side project for making PIL's resize code vectorizable as it's currently -ftree-vectorize-proof
@acdha +1, although I don't think resize() should return a copy
it doesn't help that PILs development state is a bag of WTF (IMO)
Too many things depend on it to let it just stagnate like this
@alex that won't stop me from asking you

@alex Something like that - it seems like it'd be really nice if, say, you could reliable do something like Image.open("foo.jpg") .resize(256, 256) .save("thumb.jpg", "JPEG") even if the underlying implementations had substantial differences (e.g. if someone on Jython chose to wrap the Java2D stuff)
e.g. you can fix bugs in the stdlib without knowing about the JIT
Really the right approach is imaging, and _imaging or something
where imaging is the wrappers and _imaging is implemented by the platform to do th heavy lifting
Yes
